This PR adds AoT support using the `ngc` compiler. `@ngtools/webpack` still has many flaws, but this setup is working perfectly. `npm install` and then `npm run ci` to fully test both AoT and JIT builds.

- upgraded Angular to ~2.4.1
- added AoT compile script
- fixed AoT incompatible code in app
- enabled Webpack 2 tree shaking by specifying ES2015 module output
- e2e testing script launches its own server
- ci script will test both AoT and JIT builds, makes fresh builds on each test
- specified `noEmit` typescript flag to prevent accidentally spamming compiled files into the project
- disabled caching on production server to be able to see changes
- updated bad links at top of README
- documented new features in README

Resolves #885

@colinskow - I'll take a look at this in the morning.

//cc @gdi2290 @katallaxie should also take a look

@colinskow - I'll take a look at this in the morning.

//cc @gdi2290 @katallaxie should also take a look

@katallaxie - AOT should not be the default for `prod` for exactly what @colinskow stated, it breaks things. After a developer has his application running stable on AoT, he or she can default it to AoT in their project. We should be enabling features in a starter, not mandating them.

Given the commitment required to create a large application published AoT, this is a feature that should be off by default & opt in or it's going to break every production build this starter backs when they pick up the changes.

I do on the other hand agree about @katallaxie's comment in regards to the BundleAnalyzerPlugin, It's trivial to add and would suggest this be transfered to Wiki instructions & not added to the seed directly ( it's big ).

We get basic bundle analysis via Webpack RC, if people want all the bells & whistles they can add `BundleAnalyzerPlugin`

@colinskow I get your point. Though, I believe it should be considered best practice to have AoT and deviate from that. So, if you have an application, that for what ever reasons, doesn't work with AoT then you can disable it. But I would see it the other way around. As regarding to `@ngtools/webpack`, I had doubts some months ago, that's why it wasn't in the `aot` branch. Though, I see it as the tool of choice in the long run. You have less boilerplate code, better integration with what Webpack does and better code quality.

bug report
report a *bug* After typescript 2.0.6 the build process stuck at loading js. No debug error happens but seems infinite burning CPU.

Stuck point: 

Project is running at http://localhost:8888/
webpack output is served from /
Content not from webpack is served from xxxxxxxx
404s will fallback to /index.html                                                                                                67% building modules 1165/1226 modules 61 active ...

No debug log and nothing different to verbose mode.
I also switch between node from 7.2.1 to 6.9.2 nothing changed.
The stuck point is building a module that if I remove that module it stuck to another one. so something general must be wrong during the module js file loading.


Solution is to fix the typescript version to 2.0.6 instead of ^2.0.6

bug report
report a *bug* After typescript 2.0.6 the build process stuck at loading js. No debug error happens but seems infinite burning CPU.

Stuck point: 

Project is running at http://localhost:8888/
webpack output is served from /
Content not from webpack is served from xxxxxxxx
404s will fallback to /index.html                                                                                                67% building modules 1165/1226 modules 61 active ...

No debug log and nothing different to verbose mode.
I also switch between node from 7.2.1 to 6.9.2 nothing changed.
The stuck point is building a module that if I remove that module it stuck to another one. so something general must be wrong during the module js file loading.


Solution is to fix the typescript version to 2.0.6 instead of ^2.0.6

In addition to @d3viant0ne 's [commit](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/6193e308f29c82f3cbda4395f487a111a10f7e48#diff-b9cfc7f2cdf78a7f4b91a753d10865a2) of 9-Dec, I had to set `"@angular/forms": "2.2.1"` (use to be `^2.2.1`, which brought me `v2.3.0`). As I forked `angular2-webpack-starter` before [that commit](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/306672798cf5865037ccba37ac7aa4feb89c2110#diff-b9cfc7f2cdf78a7f4b91a753d10865a2) of 23-Nov, it was `^2.2.1` just for the `@angular/forms`.

So my full fix was:

1. Modified `package.json` to set:

- `"typescript": "2.1.1"` (use to be `^2.0.6`, which brought me `v2.1.4`)
- `"@angular/forms": "2.2.1"` (use to be `^2.2.1`, which brought me `v2.3.0`, when other `@angular/` were `2.2.1`). As an alternative, you can make them all `^2.2.1` and it will work again as all `@angular/` versions will be aligned.

2. Deleted corresponding folders in `node_modules` and ran `npm install`. For some reason, running `npm install` straight away didn't work (something was cached?).

The current material2 branch is broken, it doesnt even contain material2. It might a good idea to add a how-to-get-material2 working page in the wiki?

My steps

> npm i --save node-sass sass-loader material 


in app.module.ts import material 2 and load it


in webpack.common.js under resolve add .scss to the extensions

under module.rules add 



in the src/assets folder create a scss folder and insert a index.scss with this line (or whatever theme you need)

`@import '~@angular/material/core/theming/prebuilt/pink-bluegrey.scss';`


in app.component.ts replace styleUrls with

`  styles: [require('../assets/scss/index.scss').toString()],`

I did this twice. Forgot the second time what i needed to do to get it working, I think others will encounter this too.

@maxx0r  @d3viant0ne
Angular Material integration is quite straight forward.

Saying that, if you are using bootstrap loader and saas loader like, it's very easy to include material scss.

in **.bootstraprc** add the below line.

`appStyles: PATH_TO_YOUR_APPLICATION_SCSS`

and in your **APPLICATION_SCSS** add the material theme imports. You can use any theme here.

`@import '~@angular/material/core/theming/prebuilt/pink-bluegrey.scss';`

But I am wondering, is there any way to choose the themes dynamically?

Rolling the state back up the tree to a `single source of truth` prevents you from mutating shared state which will have unintended / undesired side effects in your application that are extremely difficult to run down in a large application. In short, you want as many dumb components as is humanly possible.

What Patrick implemented is very similar to `ngrx` in a lot of ways. For instance if you look  [here](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/src/app/app.service.ts#L19-L22) this implementation attempts to prevent people from mutating state directly, leading to the issue described above.

Inevitably you will need to maintain state in your application and inevitably you will need your applications components to communicate. Angular2 is designed to flow data / state down and events up. Your lower level components simply take `@Input()` & `@Output()` which makes them reusable and easier to maintain / test. As your application grows, this approach also makes it much easier to reason about your application state given you always know the beginning and end of every state change.

As an aside, this implementation is also very simple to convert to use something like `ngrx` should you or your team decide you want to leverage that particular suite of tools.

Seems to be related with protractor updating to work with TS2.

Got e2e tests running again by updating the following:

`"@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.53.33",`
`"protractor": "4.0.10",`

and removed:

`"@types/protractor": "^1.5.20",`

also don't forget to remove `"protractor",` from tsconfig `compoilerOptions` as well:



(since protractor comes with their own typings now).

And next add the required imports to *.e2e.ts files like ([ref](https://github.com/angular/protractor/tree/master/exampleTypescript)):

`import { browser, by } from 'protractor';`
To fix this error with  "protractor": "^4.0.14" I needed to also remove @types/selenium-webdriver as protractor now includes these types also

tslint update
- **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
  - Tslint 3.9.x have a bug while dealing with wilcards
  - Codelyzer rules have not been used
  - Recommended rules hard coded.
- **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
  - TSlint update to `@next`
  - Recommended Codelyzer rules being used in a separate file.
  - Extend recommended rules.
  - Update all code to follow new rules
- **Other information**:

This somehow is related to #1091 and #1084. But instead of **just follow the style guide** I updated the TSLint to linter the style guide with `codelyzer`.

Other dependencies do not support tslint 4.x, resubmit a PR when both Codelyzer & tslint-loader all support the newer version of tslint. Merging something for 4.x / @next will fail peerDeps breaking nodejs 4.x builds.

Agree with @katallaxie - This doesn't belong in a `starter` repo. Electron, although something I really like is situational at best. This is a great idea but just not something that belongs in this repo.

My suggestion would be to go the route that @NathanWalker with https://github.com/NathanWalker/angular-seed-advanced

Fork the starter, make your additions & squash them into a single commit to make it easier to pick up changes from upstream and once it's in good shape, I'm sure @gdi2290 wouldn't have an issue with adding a link to the README.md to make it easier to find your version of the `advanced starter`

The release notes for v5.0.5 are misleading. The release notes show:

>  v5.0.5 - 52b4d4e
> Title: Angular 2
> @katallaxie katallaxie released this on Sep 2 Â· 35 commits to master since this release
> 
> @angular/*-2.0.0

The above suggests that the latest version (5.0.5) is on Angular 2.0.0, but taking a look at the package.json file, angular is still only on RC6. A long away off 2.0.0.

Manually updating package.json to 2.0.0 or 2.1.0 has no effect due to npm shrinkwrap forcing it back down to RC6.

3 questions:
1. Can the release notes be updated to be clear that this is NOT 2.0.0, but it is RC6. Or if the chosen commit for that tag was incorrect, and it should be 2.0.0, can the tag be updated.
2. The code in master is on angular 2.0.0, but using latest master (039deb5) causes other dependancy warnings. What is the most stable 2.0.0 commit, if there is one. Is perhaps the 2.1.0 branch more stable/ready yet?
3. What are the pros/cons/reasons one would need/want to continue to use the angular class starter kit over doing webpack yourself. I like the starter kit, but having this dependancy in the middle preventing us from using the latest released version of angular is causing an issue for us. If someone could outline the pros and cons of not using the starter kit, that would be appreciated, to help decide the best course of action.

_Note: I took out all the other questions in the template bug report, as this does not apply to a specific environment, and is a question about the repo/code in general. Can provide the info if needed._

The problem occurs with the images not showing when I generate the dist files, place the generated dist files on a CDN like Akamai and access the dist files from my JBoss application. 

If my application url is jboss.com and the dist files of all the js files and my images (assets) are placed in say akamai.com, the css being served well, but since the css is part of the main.bundle.js and loaded on the DOM, it is attempting to load the image from jboss.com instead of from akamai.com. 

Only if I load the css directly on the head without including it as a StyleUrl in the Angular2 component, it will actually look for the image in the CDN and render it on the application. 

P.S: I currently have the ViewEncapsulation set to NONE.
- **What is the expected behavior?**

Expected behavior should be the image should load from the CDN.

To not place static resources like the images in the application server and serve them from a CDN.

@katallaxie , it looks like [this commit](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/7bfba744ebfa77c5dfb30524e639e394a1d92c0e#diff-f737fedb5357468044db2dbe98eb0218L39) moved the `metadata` property from the root of the config object into the  `HtmlWebpackPlugin` in `webpack.common.js` however other features relay on it for useful information (i.e: it's not only for the HtmlWebpackPlugin). Github pages is one but also [webpack.dev.js#23](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/config/webpack.dev.js#L23)  and [webpack.prod.js#27](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/config/webpack.prod.js#L27) assume it's there.

I will duplicate the `metadata` property in `webpack.common.js` to be both on root object and in `HtmlWebpackPlugin` for now to restore order.

However, some refactoring is needed since the logical process is wrong.
`HtmlWebpackPlugin` is set in `webpack.common.js` but a user might want to alter some values in dev/prod... 

It's not for this topic but I think common should have a pre process callback that can get the (almost) final config object and do some work such as adding plugins etc using updated/final objects.

I think an issue is needed for this, for now I will just duplicate to restore github pages functionality.
@katallaxie please review before I merge.

Here's how I got Sass working with Hot Module Replacement in my app. 
- In dev mode, Hot Module Replacement is enabled for Sass
- In production mode, all styles are extracted into an external .css file - to prevent "flash" of unstyled content and allow caching of css.

My loader for SCSS - works fast and easy


- `sass-vars-loader` allows you to load a JS file with exported variables, then import them into every scss file.
- `sass-resources` loads up a specified array of .scss files, and prepends them before every .scss file is compiled. Useful for appwide variables and mixins.
- `postcss` allows you to do lots of cool stuff, like autoprefix classes with vendor prefixes.

Here's how to specify the options for each of those loaders



This is where `sassVarsConfig` is defined:



Here's how to setup the `sass-js-variables.js`



Lastly, instead of using angular2's `styleUrls` or `styles` properties of the @Component decorator, I opt to do it like this instead:



I import the scss outside of the @Component decorator. Why? Because this way I get Hot Module Replacement to work on my .scss files, and it allows my styles to apply globally. I then simply namespace my .scss files with the selector for each specific component, which creates an encapsulated style to prevent it from affecting other components:



That's it.  [Here's my repo](https://github.com/IAMtheIAM/angular2-webpack2-dotnet-starter) which is a fork of this repo, that shows all this off in action. (Note: its using .NET core to host the app, so you'll need .NET Core SDK installed in order to run it)

**Note: for support questions, please use one of these channels:** [Chat: AngularClass.slack](http://angularclass.com/member-join/) or [Twitter: @AngularClass](https://twitter.com/AngularClass)

Agree with @katallaxie - While I docker everything under the sun, many still use vagrant or don't containerize at all. This as examples in the readme would accomplish the same thing while allowing flexibility to implement without the merge headaches as everyone's compose stack is going to vary significantly.

Cleanup

Less dependencies, cleaner `package.json`.
@harunurhan you remove @types/corejs,will lead to WebStrom display error.because i use webstrom
@xielongjiang Since `corejs` provided by `typescript` itself by setting `lib` in `compileOptions` of `tsconfig.json`, this shouldn't be necessary and it is the bug should be fixed by WebStorm.

Duplicate identifiers are exactly that, two libs both have the same types. Remove one or open an issue with the maintainers of the types in question.

i.e. Protractor & @types/selenium-webdriver will do this because protractor is now shipping with the same set of types.

i got the solution . run these commands

npm uninstall webpack --save-dev 
npm install webpack@2.1.0-beta.21 --save-dev
npm uninstall "@types/selenium-webdriver" --save-dev
npm install "@types/selenium-webdriver@2.44.26" --save-dev

This issue is coming on latest codebase. Very annoying related to the protractor @types.

fixing the version of @types/selenium-webdriver resolves the issue

`"@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.44.26"`
Same here with `"@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.53.33"`

Putting `"@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.44.29"` in your package.json is the latest version that does not display the error

Note: Make sure that you do not have a Caret `^` before the version number as that will cause npm to install Version the latest matching minor version which is: `"2.53.33"`.  As described above will cause this error to occur.

The readme states "We use the component approach in our starter. This is the new standard for developing Angular apps and a great way to ensure maintainable code by encapsulation of our behavior logic."

However, RC6 removed @Component.directives (deprecated in a previous RC) which indicates to me that the angular team is supporting a module pattern. it doesn't really make sense to add a bunch of declarations in your `app.module.ts` that won't be used by the entire app, but only by specific components. this might be a weak example, but `home` uses the `x-large` directive but `about` may never need to have the ability to use that directive.

Does this make sense or am I misunderstanding the Angular team's intentions?

Use the angular2-webpack-starter demo application as is (with webpack 2.1.0-beta.22 (not the latest beta.23 !) and configure the TypeScript compiler via tsconfig.json to use es2015 for both target and module.
- **What is the expected behavior?**

The application's tests should still run.
- **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**

Webpack 2.0 now supports the ES 2015 module syntax, so we should be able to configure the TypeScript compiler to emit ES2015 module syntax (import/export statements).
On top of that, since Angular 2 RC6, the Angular JavaScript sources, provided by the npm package alongside the TypeScript sources, themselves are compiled with this setting.
- **Please tell us about your environment:**
- Angular version: 2.0.0 (Final Release)
- Browser: Chrome 53.0.2785.116 m (64-bit)

There is currently a bug on the `/src/app.module.ts` file

On line 6, it imports `createInputTransfer` from `'@angularclass/hmr'`

However `createInputTransfer` is not exported by `"/node_modules/@angularclass/hmr/dist/index"`

This is then used to restore the input values of the store at `hmrOnDestroy`.

An error is thrown when navigating to the nested route:

> TypeError: Cannot read property 'routes' of undefined
- **If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem** via
  https://plnkr.co or similar (you can use this template as a starting point: http://plnkr.co/edit/tpl:AvJOMERrnz94ekVua0u5).

Given a folder structure of modules such as:

/home
/+lazy-parent
/+lazy-child

Let the app load into the home view.  Navigate directly to a nested lazy loaded route such as /lazy-parent/lazy-child.  An error is thrown:

> TypeError: Cannot read property 'routes' of undefined

If you load the application with the url already pointed to the nested lazy route, then no error is raised.  If you first navigate /lazy-parent and then later navigate to the child route no error is raised.
- **What is the expected behavior?**

Lazy route is loaded and no error is raised.
- **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**

Errors are bad.

- Angular version: 2.0.0-beta.RC6
- Browser: all

Really looking forward for DLL usage with webpack because one of [my project](https://github.com/asadsahi/AspNetCoreSpa) rebuilds in roughly 150-250 ms compared to angular2-webpack-starter takes roughly 1-1.5 seconds on same machine. That project uses DLL concept from webpack to skip vendor files. Credit to @SteveSandersonMS 's generator what this project is based on.

### Considering becoming an Angular CLI template or using @ngtools/webpack

With the Angular CLI becoming so powerful and central to workflow, it's a good time to consider if this starter makes sense to work as an Angular CLI template. See "[App Creation Using Template](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/wiki/Stories#app-creation-using-template)" in the CLI wiki. Becoming a template would look something like this for a user to get started:

`ng new my-ng2-app --template=angular2-webpack-starter`

Or adopting [`@ngtools/webpack`](https://www.npmjs.com/~ngtools) to not miss out on any of the innovations happening on the CLI like "code splitting" (see below) and other optimizations. 

See the benefits and ability to use `@ngtools/webpack` standalone from the Angular CLI as presented in [Stephen Fluin's Angular CLI talk](https://youtu.be/uBRK6cTr4Vk?t=6m45s) at Angular Connect 2016:
- Compiles SCSS/LESS
- TypeScript transpilation
- Bundles JavaScript, CSS
- Asset optimization
- Virtual filesystem for assets
  - For serving local assets and compile versions.
- Live-reload via websockets
- Code splitting
  - Recognizing the use of loadChildren in the router, and bundling those modules separately so that any dependencies of those modules are not going to be loaded as part of your main bundle. These separate bundles will be pulled out of the critical path of your application, making your total application bundle much smaller and loading it much more performant.

The next change to the repo would diverge from the current folder structure and the current style guide with the focus on production apps. The change would also include AoT,  DLL only for dev and SCSS (since it's the most popular one). Anything the CLI has will be included plus more depending on the opinions and style guide of @AngularClass. The only problem right now is finding the weekend to work on it or start training maintainers for future updates. The CLI and starter repos have different goals which is why this repo will always exist.

Given @gdi2290 is already implementing this in the Angular2 seed, would it not make more sense to simply port that over to the webpack starter. Consistency ftw :)
@eslammostafa I have the same issue. How did you fix it?

- **I'm submitting a ...**
  [X] question about the decisions made in the repository

@katallaxie

While the enthusiasm is great, just slamming home changes without others having the opportunity to vet those changes kind of defeats the point of `community` & `code review`. 30 Commits directly to master, to include those to fix or remove features that shouldn't have landed between 27 Sept & 01 Aug.

It also means that everyone that uses the webpack-starter as a base project has to pick up those changes and merge them into what is usually a modified project, it gets tedious quickly.

I'm suggesting you start delivering changes as `complete, tested & vetted sets of work` through the standard `pull request` workflow that everyone else uses thus making the update process less labor intensive and less prone to blowing up peoples forks (which happened to me last week). 

`Landing your own code` is generally `frowned upon` and for good reason. A second ( or multiple ) sets of eyes is never, ever a bad thing.

![screen shot 2016-09-02 at 8 23 50 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8420490/18205263/a9dad192-70e6-11e6-8701-664f551ede99.png)

![screen shot 2016-09-02 at 8 23 50 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8420490/18205263/a9dad192-70e6-11e6-8701-664f551ede99.png)

//cc @gdi2290

This was in my PR https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/pull/944. Which I had @gdi2290 ask to comment on. The changes were perhaps a bit more complicated; but it was to the final removal of some APIs.
@gdi2290 I have updated to RC6. There seems to be an issue with the `DedupePlugin`. Should we move ahead anyway? See https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/1587

this fixes #867
- **Other information**:

in response to @gdi2290 comment on #867

Hey @HansS sorry we weren't more transparent and thanks for purchasing the Master Bundle. We have the courses on a new schedule that is not reflected on the website and the order might change up a bit. This is mostly due to fit Angular 2's release which is very soon and due to the recent changes in `2.0.0-rc.5`. We thought it would be better if we recreate the courses using the new approach after Angular 2 is released. The delay of the reactive course is mostly my fault going back and forth with @Hendrixer on if we should teach our new reactive architecture that we have, or to use the [angular2-observe-decorators](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-observe-decorators), or to focus only on reactivity and state management (our original plan). We were also thinking about if we should teach more RxJS or move that into the Modern JavaScript course or provide that as a mini-course. We decided to stick with our original plan because the observe-decorators is teaching a new way to manage your app with my own proposed spec that might change if it's merged with the Angular codebase. Our new reactive architecture has all of the features that everyone is talking about (rxjs, redux, sagas, effects) plus a ton of features that no-one is talking about (past/present/future states, interop, priority rendering, isolated loops, hot module replacement, webworkers, universal) and would need a few more iterations to unify the whole story. A lot of sugar is needed before we release it to make the API more intuitive and will most likely be a free course.

**Note: for support questions, please use one of these channels:** [Chat: AngularClass.slack](http://angularclass.com/member-join/) or [Twitter: @AngularClass](https://twitter.com/AngularClass)

Hi,

don't know if its the right place to ask here but I'm 
trying to get this repo work with bootstrap 4 mixins.

I followed the wiki bootstrap 4 guide and everything
looks good.

But if I have an component for instance 

**home.component.ts**



and **home.style.scss**

`@include media-breakpoint-up(md) {
    .dosomething {
         padding: 0px;
    }
}`

I get 'No mixin named media-breakpoint-up'.

If i add the following line to **home.style.scss**
it works. But I don't know it it's the right thing todo.



So is it possible to inject _breakpoints.scss (mixins) and _variables.scss 
global or if its needed? Shouldn't webpack handle this case?

Regards

I got this to work by importing `@import "../../../node_modules/bootstrap/scss/bootstrap-grid.scss";` instead of the breakpoints directly. The Bootstrap-Grid file does include the breakpoints along with other pieces.

Agree with @qdouble here. As it stands right now, I'm loving AoT but I have implemented it professionally in a similar fashion to Anthony, separate tasks executed explicitly. @ngtools/webpack has some outstanding issues that are blocking it's usefulness.

Small implementation details aside, the only really viable way to get AoT working in a meaningful way would be the route @qdouble took. Kind of wish I would have seen his starter prior to doing all that work myself :/ as we ended up in a similar place.

_**If the intent is to get AoT into this starter sooner rather than later,  qdouble/angular-webpack2-starter would be the path forward.**_ 

That said, there are some pretty significant challenges with AoT once you grow your application to anything of production size. `AoT is a commitment to building in a specific way`, most of which won't be apparent with the small starter application. For instance, anyone using Sass in the normal fashion of using require statements in components for styles are going to have a lot of work to do. 

If we are going to land AoT now, everyone should be ready for the onslaught of questions and issues when people try to pull in AoT enabled #master and their builds explode ( been there ... lol ). 

Also worth noting, if we are going to release AoT support we definitely need to test the AoT builds for PRs or we are going to be breaking master every other day ( been there too ).

As far as I understand this, the Webpack Starter is not using (anymore) Typings, but instead the "@types" that comes with the new version of typescript.

So to solve your problem, first look if there is a "@types" for GSAP.

Else, you can try to paste the content of you ".d.ts" file in the "custom-typings.d.ts" of the Webpack Starter.

- I have a project on which I've used this excellent starter as a base. Each time there are updates, I've updated my application - everything's been smooth.

Since Typescript2 its possible to use es2015 declarations with `target: es5` specified.
And we can drop `@types/core-js` from deps.

See: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/What's-new-in-TypeScript#including-built-in-type-declarations-with---lib

- **Do you want to request a _feature_ or report a _bug_?**
  Report a possible bug.
- **What is the current behavior?**
  Running tests with karma auto-watch active (npm run watch:test) does not always trigger the correct results, as it seems something is not fetching the correct last version of the code.
- **If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem** 

Steps:
- clone the project
- npm install
- npm run watch:test
- \- the test are sucessfull
- change src/app.component.ts line 58 `url = 'https://twitter.com/AngularClass';` to `url = 'https://twitter.com/AngularClassXXXX'`
- the tests are **not sucessfull, which is correct**
- undo the change made on src/app.component.ts line 58
- the tests are **not sucessfull, which is incorrect**

So the **first change in code** after karma starts is always triggered, then the strange behaviour happens (cant find a pattern)

- **I'm submitting a ...**
  [x ] question about the decisions made in the repository
- **What is the current behavior?**
  The package.json file lists project dependencies. 
  I noticed that a lot of the "project" packages, for example @angular/\*  are  listed in the dependencies section.

I assume that when a project is built, all dependencies are put into the bundle files.
Therefore I would assume that all the files in the "dependencies" section really should be in the "devDependencies" section.

Let's for example say that you want to add a node backend (which is reasonable to think). 
You would install packages for the backend, and when you deploy the application you would copy your backend source to the destination server, and then run "npm install --production"

This would effectively install all the @angular/\* packages in the production environment. A behaviour you don't want. Npm install --production installs all packages listed in the "dependencies" section.

So my question is:
Is there something I've completely missed - or should we not move all packages into the "devDependencies" section?

If not, how would you distinct packages to be installed in a production environment, when adding a node backend?

Cheers, guys, really appreciate this project, it has helped me tremendously in setting up the exact environment I need for my projects.

Hi, i think is more about concept than about actual use, off course you can put `@angular` dependencies in dev since most users just install in production by uploading the bundled files and installing the server deps.

The concept i talk is that devDeps are the deps you need during development (mostly webpack, browserify, gulp...) and in normal deps goes the ones your app really use (like @angular/core) so it's about stating in the package that deps are the ones your app requires and devDeps are the ones you use to bundle, compile or deploy your app.

If you need data from server best approach to use Http service from '@angular/http'. Because it has required change detection code.

@holiber how did you find out that this is a Chrome 51 problem? How did you fix it?

Using `git bisect` today, I found out that the introduction of `momentjs` into our builds broke source maps on Chrome Version 51.0.2704.103 (64-bit).

Webpack config has `devtool: 'cheap-module-source-map'`.

A fix for us was to include either of the following as a Webpack plugin:
- `new webpack.ContextReplacementPlugin(/moment[\/\\]locale$/, /en-us/)`
- `new webpack.IgnorePlugin(/^\.\/locale/, /moment$/)` 

Note that the first solution works but is broken, since there's no `en-us` files in `moment/locale` for v2.13.0 - I just got it via copy-pasta from another project. The second solution should be preferred.

Ping @lanceharper @ccastarivale; this happened in https://github.com/trueprint/arivale-coach-client/commit/37b7a12b54e4068613b5d487c6cb12bda7a77823.

- [`f5c6225`](https://github.com/survivejs/webpack-merge/commit/f5c6225ddeb81e99a79eff87334386b49fa2b013) `Merge pull request #22 from mshwery/master`
- [`a458cc8`](https://github.com/survivejs/webpack-merge/commit/a458cc831f272fffd3188e27f7a17d472e8245de) `use array slice instead of Array.from`
- [`a578608`](https://github.com/survivejs/webpack-merge/commit/a578608f10d76e9ee11ff98aebfc4fb9dc65ed0f) `add test case for smart merges with identical include/exclude, and make it pass`

I am currently working on a fork with this feature. I currently have a private repo with it until it is stable.

If your interested in helping out I can invite you to it. Mainly I am mixing https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter with https://github.com/NathanWalker/angular2-seed-advanced.

here is my plans for it and current state:

@RicardoVaranda is correct. The original issue is related to `typings` and this project has moved on to `@types`. That said, if you get an error like this you have a typescript problem and should begin by looking at  your `types` array in the `tsconfig.json`

thanks for the feedback, @gdi2290! i changed the files accordingly.

I've also noticed that the @RouteConfig in app.ts uses a loader for the async about component which is required(). I assume that this is the reason that it is separated into its own webpack bundle. But I still would like some more information about how this all fits together.

For next people having that problem:
webpack config:
{ test: /.scss$/, loaders: ['raw-loader','sass-loader'] },

component:
styles: [require('./component.scss')],

.scss file:
@import "./node_modules/bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/variables";
`npm run typings-install` uses the local version (the one installed and lives in `node_modules`) of typings so you probably need to update your global version `npm install -g typings` cc @blakeembrey
@gdi2290 How did you generate the file structure tree diagram? And does it get updated to the README.md whenever there is a change made to the files / folders?

@RemKolomna can you share what you're doing right now. To install from DefinitelyTyped, you can do `typings install jquery --ambient --save` - it's better to use non-ambient modules where available, but jQuery has already been typed so you might as well make use of it :smile: 

As for the additional issues, I know Angular has some binding so the global `$` so you might have to do something there. If you can provide a link I can quickly review what you've done, that'll make it easier.
I'm not using typings anymore, just including` "@types/jquery": "^2.0.34"` in my package.json file.

Got it to work.

@valorkin I had already installed `moment` via tsd.

What I had to do was the following.

**1. Reference the `tsd.d.ts` generated by `tsd` in `src/typings/_custom.d.ts`.**



Not sure that's the right place, but it definitely worked and looks clean to me.

**2. Moving the tsd typings to `src/typings` for more consistency**

Obviously this is not needed, but I found it more intuitive to have a single app-wide `typings` folder. For doing so I added a `tsd.json` ([src here](https://github.com/juristr/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/simple-component/tsd.json)). Maybe we should include this in this starter by default? What's your view on this @gdi2290 ? or does it interfere with your plans from issue #122 ?

**3. Change the `moment` import as suggested by @valorkin**

TypeScript autocompletion now works as expected

This PR adds `ng2-bootstrap` (as requested in https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/pull/83). `ng2-bootstrap` provides the ng2 components, `bootstrap` is purely used for the CSS file. The latter could be replaced with a CDN version, but I prefer to be able to work offline which is why I added also the `bootstrap` dependency.

To make things work, I had to [remove the `/node_modules/` regex](https://github.com/dotcs/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/f6a520138588300f27d6b1042f3d534117c23749#diff-11e9f7f953edc64ba14b0cc350ae7b9dL131) in webpack's typescript module loader definition. I tried to only include the `ng2-bootstrap` module - without success. The regex `node_modules\/((?!(ng2-bootstrap)).)*` did not work, although it should exclude all but the `ng2-bootstrap` folder. If the exclusion of `node_modules` is necessary for any other parts of this project, we should find a way around this issue before merging.

/cc: @gdi2290
exclusion of `node_modules` is for performance reasons. perhaps @valorkin (creator of ng2-bootstrap) can provide some insight otherwise LGTM

BINDINGS will be deprecated soon, so we use PROVIDERS instead. Also remove unnecessary @View

@gdi2290 What is the recommended approach to use the examples? If the idea is to copy&paste the code to the `src` folder, @zarkosusnjar's PR should be accepted (and we should check all other imports in the examples, too). I thought that the main idea is to switch examples via webpack config as described in my post above. But reading example's README sounds like the recommended approach is more or less to copy&paste the code ...

We could also use webpack to resolve the examples automatically by adding the examples folder to the resolved variables like it's done [here](https://github.com/angular-class/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/webpack.config.js#L97) for 'rx'. Then we could always write `import {Home} from 'examples/simple-component/home/home';` regardless of where the file that needs the import is located at. It's a matter of taste, so which way do you prefer?

Switching via webpack config is my preferred solution. IMHO it's more convenient. I'd go that way.

For me the current setup works with node 4.2.1 and npm 2.14.7 on Mac OS X 10.10. @gsans, @byleaf Can you update node and npm and give us an update if everything works fine now?

If the dependencies have been installed with node 0.x and later node 4.x is being used to update the packages, this might indeed be a problem that leads to an inconsistent state. The easiest solution here is to delete `node_modules` as mentioned above and re-install dependencies using the latest npm.

This PR makes use of Bootstrap 3.3.5 and jQuery 2.1.4. It demonstrates the usage of the tooltip plugin. I would suggest that you don't merge this to master, but make a separate branch that includes Bootstrap.

The PR should fix #16 and #61.

Please note, that it was necessary to include a modified version of the jQuery description (`jquery.d.ts`) to make this work with the rest of the setup. The fix has been provided by [@chaosmail](https://github.com/borisyankov/DefinitelyTyped/issues/2734#issuecomment-118950111). Details on this topic can be found there.

To get e2e tests running, I had to fix some issues with Protractor/Selenium. First of all I had to adjust the port of the `baseUrl` to `3000` since the webpack dev server is running on this port. 

Then I ran into an issue in which it was impossible to get the WebDriver session started. This is documented [here](https://github.com/angular/angular-seed/issues/251). The [solution](https://github.com/angular/angular-seed/issues/251#issuecomment-129217595) by @josefsalyer worked for me, so I suggest to use it in this repo as well.
This is all set. /cc @gdi2290
@abhishekisnot can you submit a PR with jsdoc?

@gdi2290 , with regards to our discussion on gitter, Can you help me establish the following workflow using this project structure?  

Deployment
- Deploy 1 or more bundles to CDN
- Deploy index.html and config.json to server.

Bundles are packaged dependencies:
- Typescript with classes and imports transpiled to ES5, minified and obfuscated.
- LESS with @imports transpiled to CSS and minified
- vendor minified js and css.
- images (png,gif,jpgâ€¦) minified.
- fonts and svg

Build conditional resources:
